metadata.case_name: Kajori Lal Agarwal v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant Kajori Lal Agarwal was the owner-in-khas of 37.85 acres of land in Mouza Shibnath Das J.L. No. 110 and Mouza Kholai Singh J.L. No. 112 in Siliguri Town, district of Darjeeling.

Lands acquired by Union of India (respondent 1) and State of West Bengal (respondent 2) under West Bengal Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948 for Assam Rail Link Project. Respondent No. 3 is Land Acquisition Officer, Darjeeling.
Appellant claimed compensation at Rs. 100 per cottah amounting to Rs. 2,27,100 plus Rs. 8,000 on account of severance and other grounds.
Respondent No. 3 made award under s.7 of the Act on 5th February, 1951 directing payment of Rs. 22,074 at Rs. 600 per acre.
Notice served on appellant under s.12(2) of Land Acquisition Act, 1894.
On 21st March, 1951, appellant accepted the amount under protest.
Appellant filed application before respondent No. 3 on 2nd February, 1953 claiming reference to Court under s.8 of the Act alleging award grossly inadequate.
Respondent No. 3 rejected application as barred by time.
Appellant moved Calcutta High Court in Civil Revision Case No. 676 of 1954 challenging the rejection.

On 16th June, 1955, Division Bench of Calcutta High Court allowed revision, remanded to respondent No. 3 directing to deal with application in accordance with law, observing no prescribed limitation but must be within reasonable time (Kajori Lal Agarwal v. Union of India Ors., 59 C.W.N. 1936).

On 12th January, 1953, Calcutta High Court ruled in Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar v. Union of India (Civil Rule No. 2940 of 1951, 57 C.W.N. 283) that no prescribed period of limitation for application under s.8.
After remand, appellant filed affidavit on 27th August, 1956 explaining reasons for delay.
On 10th September, 1956, respondent No. 3 rejected application again for not moving within reasonable time.
Appellant filed Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956 in Calcutta High Court under Art. 227 Constitution read with s.115 CPC.
On 6th July, 1959, Division Bench dismissed the application, seeing no reason to interfere.
Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.8 of the West Bengal Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948 prescribes a period of limitation for making an application for reference to Court by applying provisions of s.18 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 mutatis mutandis.

petitioner_arguments.text: Calcutta High Court erred in not reversing respondent No. 3's decision; delay explained by knowledge of Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar case (12 Jan 1953) ruling no limitation, after which advised to apply.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar v. Union of India (57 C.W.N. 283); earlier Calcutta High Court ruling in own case (59 C.W.N. 1936)

petitioner_arguments.text: No prescribed period of limitation under s.8 of the Act; only reasonable time required.

respondent_arguments.text: Application for reference barred by time; neglected to move within reasonable time.

court_reasoning.text: s.8(2) of WB Act makes provisions of LA Act 1894 applicable mutatis mutandis in respect of any reference intended, proposed, or asked to be made, including application stage; thus s.18(2) LA Act limitation applies to application under s.8(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clause 'in respect of any reference made to the Court' includes pre-reference proceedings like application; rejects High Court view limiting to post-reference.

court_reasoning.text: Mandatory 'shall' in s.8(1) does not exclude limitation; similar to s.18(1) LA Act which is subject to s.18(2) limitation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature unlikely to leave applications to parties' sweet-will without time limit.

court_reasoning.text: Amendment to s.8(2) by Act VIII of 1954 expressly includes s.18(2) LA Act, supporting application to reference applications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need for amendment if High Court view correct.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's original application on 2 Feb 1953 barred by s.18(2) LA Act limitation periods (six weeks from award if present, or six weeks from notice/six months from award).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to consider reasonable time plea.

holdings.text: s.8(2) of WB Act incorporates s.18(2) LA Act limitation for applications under s.8(1); appellant's application time-barred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kajori Lal Agarwal v. Union of India Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier Calcutta HC ruling no limitation under s.8 but reasonable time; overruled by SC interpretation

precedents_cited.case_name: Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar Another v. Union of India Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Ruled no prescribed limitation under s.8; relied by appellant for delay explanation

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948 (No. 2 of 1948)
sections: s.8(2) as amended by Act VIII of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing acquisition; s.8 requires reference on application/disagreement; s.8(2) applies LA Act mutatis mutandis including limitation

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (No. 1 of 1894)
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied mutatis mutandis via s.8(2) WB Act; s.18 prescribes limitation for reference applications

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction invoked in Calcutta HC proceedings

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Read with Art.227 for Calcutta HC jurisdiction

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order confirmed on grounds that s.8(2) WB Act incorporates s.18(2) LA Act limitation, rendering appellant's application for reference time-barred.

key_quotes.text: "the provisions of the Central Act shall mutatis mutandis apply in respect of any reference intended, proposed, or asked, to be made, and not in respect of any reference already made."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of s.8(2) including application stage for limitation

key_quotes.text: "It would be unreasonable to hold that until a reference is made, the said provisions do not apply and it is only after the reference is made that the said provisions begin to operate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects High Court view limiting LA Act to post-reference proceedings

key_quotes.text: "On principle, it seems extremely unlikely that the Act could have intended to leave it to the sweet-will of the parties to make an application for reference at any time they like."
key_quotes.speaker: court
